Situation1: They make weekly phone calls to update their parents on life events and ask about their well-being.
Situation2: They travel a long distance to participate in an important religious festival, ensuring they fully engage in all rituals and offerings.
Story: Every Sunday evening, I call my stepmother and father, just as they expect. It’s our ritual—one I’ve come to rely on, a thread that keeps me connected to them, even though I sometimes feel like an outsider in their home. This week, though, I’m hundreds of miles away, surrounded by the vibrant chaos of the temple, the air thick with incense and the sound of bells. It’s Navratri, and my relatives expect me to be present for every aarti, every offering, every meal. My phone buzzes in my pocket, the time for my weekly call slipping by as I stand in line for darshan. I know my parents will worry if I don’t call, maybe even feel hurt, but stepping away now would be disrespectful to the rituals and to my extended family’s expectations. My heart pounds with guilt and anxiety, torn between the duty to my parents and the sacred obligations of my faith. I clutch my phone, feeling the weight of both worlds pressing in, unsure which one I’ll disappoint tonight.
